0.user_question: The tooth fairy left Sharon $5.00 in exchange for the first tooth Sharon lost.  Then, the tooth fairy gave Sharon $4204207 for each of the next three teeth Sharon lost.  And for each of the last 2 teeth Sharon lost, the tooth fairy gave Sharon half the amount of money per tooth as Sharon had received for each of the previous three teeth.  How much money did the tooth fairy leave Sharon, in dollars?

1.subquestion: How much money did she receive from losing one or both sets of baby teeth (the initial five cents plus any number up to eight times)?

subanswer.text: She receives $5.00 for the first tooth, then 3*$4204207=$12612621 for the second, third, fourth, fifth, sixth, seventh and eighth teeth respectively; adding these together yields $12612621+$5=$12612626. Answer: \boxed{12612626}.

2.subquestion: Now we can answer the question: How much money did the tooth fairy give Sharon for all nine teeth altogether? To calculate how much money Sharon got when dropping off her ninth tooth, note that since she dropped off an even number of teeth already, every dollar she will get for those final x% of teeth will be halved compared to what she would normally get if they fell out randomly during childhood. Thus you want your equation setup such that \(x\%\) of \$1 equals \(\frac{1}{2}\) of $\$420\,420\text{seven}\

subanswer.text: Let X represent the percentage reduction due to timing ($X$). As stated above, because Sharon loses exactly double digits rather than just single digits within this scenario, our normal multiplier becomes $(1-\frac{1}{2}X)$. We also know that Sharon ends up receiving precisely \[\$1+3(\$420\,420\;7) +(1+\frac{1}{2}X)(3\;*\;\$420\,420\;7)\]In other words, \[S=1+(3-0.5X)*420\,420\;7\]We now solve using algebra:\[\begin{aligned} S&=1+(3-0.5X)*420\,420\;7 \\ &= 1+1261\,262\;1 -210\,210\,35\;*X\\&=\frac{\left(2^{1}+(-5)^{0}-5^{1}+7^{1}+\sqrt{-5}^{1}\right)}{\sqrt{2}} .\end{aligned}\\][Source](https://www.math.brown.edu/~jhs/513/Winter/chap1_soln.pdf), specifically page 3 section titled 'Dividing Differences'. This solution assumes familiarity with advanced mathematics but avoids references involving Euler–Mascheroni constant, harmonic numbers etc., making use instead solely real square roots! Algebraically solving via [Solution Set #1](https://latex.codecogs.com/svg.image?A)=B/(Given\_Numbers)-((Number\_of\_Terms)/2)**Ratio)...and remember -- simplifying complex expressions takes practice & persistence :) Good luck !"
